name: containerboard production, linerboard, kraftliner | turpentine | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/17914/documentation

This dataset has been extrapolated from respective regional geographies (RER). This dataset represents the production of kraftliner from virgin wood/ sulfate pulp. Kraftliner is commonly produced from virgin material, while testliner is made from recycled fibers. Nonetheless also Kraftliner can partly be made from recycled fiber input. Both products are used interchangeably as bottom and top layers surrounding the mid layer of “medium” in the production of corrugated board. Data represent the industry average in 2021.;Data for the production of Kraftliner were provided by the industry association CCB (Cepi ContainerBoard). The data for Semichemical Fluting and Kraftliner jointly represent ca. 84% of the total annual production of corrugated base papers from primary fibres in Europe. Primary data were provided by large mills in Austria, Finland, France, Portugal, Poland, and Sweden. Together these mills produced 4 698 905 tonnes of paper products in 2020. Thereby each mill has a production volume of about 94 000 and 467 000 tonnes net saleable paper product (FEFCO, 2021). FEFCO. 2021. European Database for Corrugated Board Life Cycle Studies 2021. Reference(s): https://www.fefco.org/sites/default/files/documents/2022-07-07_FEFCO%20LCA%202021.pdf, last accessed March 2023;In FEFCO 2021 fuel consumption and the related emission to air include only steam and net electricity used on site. Sold electricity is not reported as a sold product and the associated input and output data are not included in the inventory. The fuel consumption and emissions to air associated with the total heat production and the net electricity used on site were allocated to the paper production.;The following air emissions were reported in the study: Particulates, <2.5μm, Particulates, >2.5μm and <10μm, Particulates, >10μm, CO2 (fossil), CO2 (biomass), CO, NOx (as NO2), SOx (as SO2), TRS (H2S as S);For a more complete air emission profile for Kraftliner production, however, additional air emissions (beyond the ones listed above) were added for the combustion of the external fuels and internal using LCI datasets for combustion of different fuels as proxy. The air emissions were calculated based on the mix of the external and internal fuels in the study and more information about the fuel mix and the proxy are provided under "Extrapolations". No proxy was available for the combustion of black liquor and "other internal fuels". Emissions from this internal energy generation processes are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry.

The process for the production of kraftliner starts with the transportation of wood and wood chips to the mill gate.

The process ends with the production of kraftliner. Processes include chipping, screening of chips, cooking to pulp for (kraft cooking process).
category: C:Manufacturing/17:Manufacture of paper and paper products/170:Manufacture of paper and paper products/1702:Manufacture of corrugated paper and paperboard and of containers of paper a

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset has been extrapolated from respective regional geographies (RER)- Data for main producers in Europe (Austria, Finland, France, Germany, Portugal, Poland, and Sweden).
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Average of present used technology;The kraft cooking process is a highly alkaline cooking process with caustic soda and sodium sulphide as active cooking chemicals with a pulp yield of around 55%. The pulp produced is defiberized in refiners, screened and washed before being sent to the paper mill. The stock passes through one or two head boxes onto the paper machine. Kraftliner is normally a two ply product and therefore requires a paper machine with two head boxes and normally also two wires.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset has been extrapolated from respective regional geographies (RER). Additional air emissions from the combustion of fossil fuels estimated based on industrial heating datasets from the ecoinvent database: natural gas: heat production, natural gas, at industrial furnace >100kW, Europe without Switzerland; heavy fuel oil: heat production, heavy fuel oil, at industrial furnace 1MW, Europe without Switzerland; light fuel oil: heat production, light fuel oil, at industrial furnace 1MW, Europe without Switzerland; diesel: heat production, light fuel oil, at industrial furnace 1MW, Europe without Switzerland; LPG: heat production, natural gas, at industrial furnace >100kW, Europe without Switzerland; Coal: heat production, at hard coal industrial furnace 1-10MW, Europe without Switzerland; Peat: heat production, lignite briquette, at stove 5-15kW, Europe without Switzerland; biogas: heat production, natural gas, at industrial furnace >100kW, Europe without Switzerland; Biofuel (bark, scrap wood, tall oil) and bark: heat production, wood chips from industry, at furnace 1000kW, CH; refused derived fuel, biomass: heat production, wood chips from post-consumer wood, at furnace 300kW. CO2, CO and CH4 emissions from biogas were modelled as non-fossil.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: This dataset has been extrapolated from respective regional geographies (RER). Data were collected from the producers by CCB (Cepi ContainerBoard) and FEFCO (European Federation of Corrugated Board Manufacturers) for the European Database for Corrugated Board Life Cycle Studies), checked by technical experts and reviewed by the Institut für Energie- und Umweltforschung Heidelberg (ifeu). The data for Semichemical Fluting and Kraftliner jointly represent ca. 84% of the total annual production of corrugated base papers from primary fibres in Europe. Reference(s): https://www.fefco.org/sites/default/files/documents/2022-07-07_FEFCO%20LCA%202021.pdf, last accessed March 2023

exchanges.description: Estimation based on fuel input data and emission factors from corresponding ecoinvent fuel combustion datasets (see "Extrapolations" comment). The internal fuels mainly consist of the black liquor and bark from the wood input for pulp production. Internal fuels are represented by the calculated emissions but do not have the corresponding fuel input from technosphere, because they are supplied from within the system boundaries. The amounts of internal fuels used in the process are: Black liquor (8.203 GJ/t), Bark (1.372 GJ/t), biogas and biosludge (0.087 GJ/t), Refuse derived fuel (RDF) (0.024 GJ/t), and other internal fuels (0.114 GJ/t). No proxy was available for the combustion of black liquor, Refuse derived fuel, and other internal fuels. Emissions from these internal energy generation processes are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry, other emissions constitute a data gap.

exchanges.description: Estimation based on fuel input data and emission factors from corresponding ecoinvent fuel combustion datasets (see "Extrapolations" comment). The internal fuels mainly consist of the black liquor and bark from the wood input for pulp production. Internal fuels are represented by the calculated emissions but do not have the corresponding fuel input from technosphere, because they are supplied from within the system boundaries. The amounts of internal fuels used in the process are: Black liquor (8.203 GJ/t), Bark (1.372 GJ/t), biogas and biosludge (0.087 GJ/t), Refuse derived fuel (RDF) (0.024 GJ/t), and other internal fuels (0.114 GJ/t). No proxy was available for the combustion of black liquor, Refuse derived fuel, and other internal fuels. Emissions from these internal energy generation processes are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry, other emissions constitute a data gap.

exchanges.description: Estimation based on fuel input data and emission factors from corresponding ecoinvent fuel combustion datasets (see "Extrapolations" comment). The internal fuels mainly consist of the black liquor and bark from the wood input for pulp production. Internal fuels are represented by the calculated emissions but do not have the corresponding fuel input from technosphere, because they are supplied from within the system boundaries. The amounts of internal fuels used in the process are: Black liquor (8.203 GJ/t), Bark (1.372 GJ/t), biogas and biosludge (0.087 GJ/t), Refuse derived fuel (RDF) (0.024 GJ/t), and other internal fuels (0.114 GJ/t). No proxy was available for the combustion of black liquor, Refuse derived fuel, and other internal fuels. Emissions from these internal energy generation processes are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry, other emissions constitute a data gap.

exchanges.description: Estimation based on fuel input data and emission factors from corresponding ecoinvent fuel combustion datasets (see "Extrapolations" comment). The internal fuels mainly consist of the black liquor and bark from the wood input for pulp production. Internal fuels are represented by the calculated emissions but do not have the corresponding fuel input from technosphere, because they are supplied from within the system boundaries. The amounts of internal fuels used in the process are: Black liquor (8.203 GJ/t), Bark (1.372 GJ/t), biogas and biosludge (0.087 GJ/t), Refuse derived fuel (RDF) (0.024 GJ/t), and other internal fuels (0.114 GJ/t). No proxy was available for the combustion of black liquor, Refuse derived fuel, and other internal fuels. Emissions from these internal energy generation processes are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry, other emissions constitute a data gap.

The internal fuels mainly consist of the black liquor and bark from the wood input for pulp production. Internal fuels are represented by the calculated emissions but do not have the corresponding fuel input from technosphere, because they are supplied from within the system boundaries. The amounts of internal fuels used in the process are: Black liquor (8.203 GJ/t), Bark (1.372 GJ/t), biogas and biosludge (0.087 GJ/t), Refuse derived fuel (RDF) (0.024 GJ/t), and other internal fuels (0.114 GJ/t). No proxy was available for the combustion of black liquor, Refuse derived fuel, and other internal fuels. Emissions from these internal energy generation processes are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry, other emissions constitute a data gap.
